title: Extinction Rebellion Grandparents facing arrest 'will do anything'
text:
Extinction Rebellion grandparents are willing to be arrested in London (Picture: Bec Booey)

Grandparents camping overnight on the front-lines of the Extinction Rebellion demonstration say they are unafraid of being arrested.

More than 1,000 people have been detained in London since the two-week protest began on Monday, October 7.

Hilary Toope, a retired headteacher, was taken into custody at Downing Street with her partner Tony Harris, after spending the night in a tent.

She said: ‘I have three grandchildren. I’ve been involved in other things and they don’t work. Extinction Rebellion is a remarkable force with non-violence and civil disobedience at it’s heart.

‘We are the last hope. I’ve never been arrested before but now I’d do it again, I’m prepared to do pretty much anything.’

Jane, 61, has already been arrested ‘twice this week’ (Picture: Bec Booey)

Eric Levy, 92, Sylvia Boyes, 75, Brian Larkin, 59, were ‘locked in’ together (Picture: Arkadiusz Kasperczyk)

Hilary Toope and Tony Harris were arrested at Downing Street (Picture: Tim Webster)

More than 1,000 people have been arrested since Monday (Picture: PA)

The protests will go on for a two week period (Picture: PA)

Jane, 61, a member of XR Peace Grandparents, spent the night ‘locked on’ in Trafalgar Square, holding hands with other protesters inside a sealed plastic tube.

She said: ‘I recently held my newborn grandson in my arms and I thought this grandmother is going to do everything she can.

‘We knew years ago that this was coming but we didn’t manage to get people to take notice. But now! This is the right place to be, right here in the road.

Mum jailed over 'terrifying' drunken rage on board Thomas Cook flight

‘I’ve been arrested twice this week and I will do whatever me and my little body can.’

Brian Larkin, 59, was pictured ‘locked on’ with great-grandparent Eric Levy, 92, and grandmother-of-six Sylvia Boyes, 75.

He decided to join the demonstration after reading that the seabird population had declined by 70 per cent since he was a child.

XR disruptions are currently taking place across the globe, with more than 60 cities taking part.

Demonstrators say they’re doing it for their children and grandchildren (Picture: PA)

Activists blocked London City Airport yesterday (Picture: AFP)

James Brown climbed on top of a British Airways flight (Picture: Reuters)

Families have attended the demonstration together (Picture: Maximus Richardson)

Yesterday London City Airport was hit by protesters who attempted to block the entrance with a ‘Hong Kong-style occupation of the terminal building’.

Around 50 people were arrested, with many climbing the roof or gluing themselves to the entrance of the Docklands Light Railway (DLR) station serving the airport.

Partially-sighted former Paralympic cyclist, James Brown, was also pictured climbing on top of a British Airways plane to stand up ‘for everybody’s kids’.

‘Selfish’ pensioner whose dying wife was found covered in maggots is jailed

He was also arrested at Heathrow Airport last month during a protest which saw some demonstrators attempt to disrupt flights by flying a drone.

Met Commissioner Dame Cressida Dick has insisted Scotland Yard has enough cells to hold all of the activists, but warned that officers were being taken away from tackling knife crime or safeguarding children.

She said the protesters were ‘utterly irresponsible and completely unreasonable’ for their determination to take over and occupy important arterial roads in London.

The official urged activists to demonstrate in the pedestrian area of Trafalgar Square, adding: ‘Protest lawfully or go home.’

description: Grandparents camping overnight on the front-lines of the Extinction Rebellion protests in London say they are unafraid of being arrested.
